title: Invoke
data:
The **#invoke** [extended command](/wiki/Extended_command "Extended command") allows you to activate certain objects. The only objects that can be activated this way are [crystal balls](/wiki/Crystal_ball "Crystal ball") and most [quest artifacts](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Artifacts tire after you invoke them, and you cannot do so again for `rnz(100)` turns (averages 100; can be up to 2000, but 95% of the time it is less than 400). If you invoke again too soon, "You feel that the \<artifact> is ignoring you" and 3d10 turns are added to the wait time.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) For artifacts that give temporary [extrinsics](/wiki/Extrinsic "Extrinsic"), the wait time is counted from the moment they're switched off (via an #invoke or otherwise).[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Optimal invocation schedule](#Optimal_invocation_schedule)

- [2 List of possible invocations](#List_of_possible_invocations)

- [3 Variants](#Variants)

  - [3.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [3.2 DynaHack](#DynaHack)

- [4 References](#References)

## Optimal invocation schedule

Invoking strategy is basically a trade-off between the risk of getting nothing and waiting too long. The turns to wait after a successful #invoke versus probability of success are graphed below (assuming your experience is <=17):

[![](/images/thumb/8/82/GraphWaitingTimeVersusInvokeSuccessProbability.svg/300px-GraphWaitingTimeVersusInvokeSuccessProbability.svg.png)](/wiki/File:GraphWaitingTimeVersusInvokeSuccessProbability.svg)



waiting time after successful #invoke versus probability of success of invocation

If you need the artifact reliably, such as emergency healing from the [Staff of Aesculapius](/wiki/Staff_of_Aesculapius "Staff of Aesculapius"), you should treat it like prayer - #invoke only in dire need. If you want a simple strategy for the most successful #invocations per turn, e. g. charging lots of wands with the [PYEC](/wiki/PYEC "PYEC"), you should wait 78 turns between invocations. This yields an expected wait of 180.83 turns. If you miss the time a bit, the rate of success does not go down much. Your experience level does not matter.

The optimum strategy is waiting

```
82;81;68;81;88;67;54;96;78;62;88;81;65;63;81;65 
```

turns after consecutive failed #invokes and restarting the list after successes. This yields an expected wait of 180.2354 turns.

[Robert Tupelo-Schneck](http://tupelo-schneck.org/robert/), of [liquid diet tourist](http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/a987da11a8df6d6b) fame, has [computed these numbers](http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/browse_thread/thread/5d5a6af685f3f96d/f4bb7faac4ad5e2d?#f4bb7faac4ad5e2d).

Minimizing the expected wait between success is the same as maximizing the expected rate of success per turn due to the [Renewal Theorem](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewal_theory#The_elementary_renewal_theorem "wikipedia:Renewal theory").

## List of possible invocations

- [The Eye of the Aethiopica](/wiki/The_Eye_of_the_Aethiopica "The Eye of the Aethiopica"): [branchport](/wiki/Branchport "Branchport") to another [dungeon branch](/wiki/Dungeon_branch "Dungeon branch").
- [The Eyes of the Overworld](/wiki/The_Eyes_of_the_Overworld "The Eyes of the Overworld"): provides [enlightenment](/wiki/Enlightenment "Enlightenment").
- [The Staff of Aesculapius](/wiki/The_Staff_of_Aesculapius "The Staff of Aesculapius"): heals half [HP](/wiki/HP "HP") damage, cures [sickness](/wiki/Sickness "Sickness"), un[blinds](/wiki/Blind "Blind"), un[slimes](/wiki/Slime "Slime").
- [The Orb of Detection](/wiki/The_Orb_of_Detection "The Orb of Detection"): toggles invisibility on/off.
- [The Sceptre of Might](/wiki/The_Sceptre_of_Might "The Sceptre of Might"): toggles conflict on/off.
- [The Mitre of Holiness](/wiki/The_Mitre_of_Holiness "The Mitre of Holiness"): boost in spell energy.
- [The Heart of Ahriman](/wiki/The_Heart_of_Ahriman "The Heart of Ahriman"): levitation; you can stop this levitation with '>' at will, or by invoking the Heart again, providing no other levitation sources interfere.
- [The Platinum Yendorian Express Card](/wiki/The_Platinum_Yendorian_Express_Card "The Platinum Yendorian Express Card"): charges objects like a scroll of charging with the same blessed/cursed status. Only Tourists can perform blessed charging.
- [The Orb of Fate](/wiki/The_Orb_of_Fate "The Orb of Fate"): level teleport.
- [The Longbow of Diana](/wiki/The_Longbow_of_Diana "The Longbow of Diana"): creates 7-16 uncursed arrows if uncursed, 7-21 blessed arrows if blessed, 6-11 cursed arrows if cursed.
- [The Master Key of Thievery](/wiki/The_Master_Key_of_Thievery "The Master Key of Thievery"): untraps boxes and doors with 100% success.

Invoking a non-artifact crystal ball is exactly the same as [applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") it.

## Variants

Many variants introduce new artifacts, and thus new possible invoke effects.

### SLASH'EM

[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") introduces a number of new artifacts that can be invoked:[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

- [The Candle of Eternal Flame](/wiki/The_Candle_of_Eternal_Flame "The Candle of Eternal Flame"): summons a (tame) fire elemental.
- [The Eye of the Beholder](/wiki/The_Eye_of_the_Beholder "The Eye of the Beholder"): reduces all non-undead monsters in eye's line of sight to 1/3 HP and reduces luck and alignment by 3 with luck above -9. Instadeath with luck below -9.
- [The Gauntlets of Defense](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_Defense "Gauntlets of Defense"): toggles invisibility on/off.
- [The Great Dagger of Glaurgnaa](/wiki/The_Great_Dagger_of_Glaurgnaa "The Great Dagger of Glaurgnaa"): boost in spell energy.
- [The Hand of Vecna](/wiki/The_Hand_of_Vecna_\(SLASH%27EM\) "The Hand of Vecna (SLASH'EM)"): summons 4-7 tame graveyard creatures and reduces alignment and luck by 3 with luck above -9. Does 5-24 damage to player with luck below -9.
- [Holy Spear of Light](/wiki/Holy_Spear_of_Light "Holy Spear of Light"): creates a lit field of a 12 square radius. This damages undead and demons in a 9 square radius.
- [The Storm Whistle](/wiki/The_Storm_Whistle "The Storm Whistle"): summons a (tame) water elemental.
- [The Arkenstone](/wiki/The_Arkenstone "The Arkenstone") (defunct Dwarf quest artifact): item detection.
- [The Tentacle Staff](/wiki/The_Tentacle_Staff "The Tentacle Staff") (defunct Drow quest artifact): level teleport.
- [The Pick of Flandal Steelskin](/wiki/The_Pick_of_Flandal_Steelskin "The Pick of Flandal Steelskin") (defunct Gnome quest artifact): toggles conflict on/off.
- [The One Ring](/wiki/The_One_Ring "The One Ring") (defunct Hobbit quest artifact): toggles conflict on/off.
- [The Staff of Withering](/wiki/The_Staff_of_Withering "The Staff of Withering") (defunct Lycanthrope quest artifact): boost in spell energy.

### DynaHack

In [DynaHack](/wiki/DynaHack "DynaHack"), the #invoke command is used to invoke, break or [rub](/wiki/Rub "Rub") objects depending on the item chosen.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/artifact.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1417](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.1_Release/src/artifact.c#L1417)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/artifact.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1433](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.1_Release/src/artifact.c#L1433)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/artifact.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1620](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/artifact.c#L1620)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) <http://www.angelfire.com/trek/mazewest/spoilers/arti_007e6.txt>

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.1. Click here for more information.](/images/d/d3/Nh361-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.1. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-361}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")
html:
Invoke

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

The #invoke extended command allows you to activate certain objects. The only objects that can be activated this way are crystal balls and most quest artifacts.[1]

Artifacts tire after you invoke them, and you cannot do so again for rnz(100) turns (averages 100; can be up to 2000, but 95% of the time it is less than 400). If you invoke again too soon, "You feel that the <artifact> is ignoring you" and 3d10 turns are added to the wait time.[2] For artifacts that give temporary extrinsics, the wait time is counted from the moment they're switched off (via an #invoke or otherwise).[3]

Contents

  • 1 Optimal invocation schedule
  • 2 List of possible invocations
  • 3 Variants
    • 3.1 SLASH'EM
    • 3.2 DynaHack
  • 4 References

Optimal invocation schedule

Invoking strategy is basically a trade-off between the risk of getting nothing and waiting too long. The turns to wait after a successful #invoke versus probability of success are graphed below (assuming your experience is <=17):

waiting time after successful #invoke versus probability of success of invocation

If you need the artifact reliably, such as emergency healing from the Staff of Aesculapius, you should treat it like prayer - #invoke only in dire need. If you want a simple strategy for the most successful #invocations per turn, e. g. charging lots of wands with the PYEC, you should wait 78 turns between invocations. This yields an expected wait of 180.83 turns. If you miss the time a bit, the rate of success does not go down much. Your experience level does not matter.

The optimum strategy is waiting 

82;81;68;81;88;67;54;96;78;62;88;81;65;63;81;65

turns after consecutive failed #invokes and restarting the list after successes. This yields an expected wait of 180.2354 turns.

Robert Tupelo-Schneck, of liquid diet tourist fame, has computed these numbers.

Minimizing the expected wait between success is the same as maximizing the expected rate of success per turn due to the Renewal Theorem.

List of possible invocations

  • The Eye of the Aethiopica: branchport to another dungeon branch.
  • The Eyes of the Overworld: provides enlightenment.
  • The Staff of Aesculapius: heals half HP damage, cures sickness, unblinds, unslimes.
  • The Orb of Detection: toggles invisibility on/off.
  • The Sceptre of Might: toggles conflict on/off.
  • The Mitre of Holiness: boost in spell energy.
  • The Heart of Ahriman: levitation; you can stop this levitation with '>' at will, or by invoking the Heart again, providing no other levitation sources interfere.
  • The Platinum Yendorian Express Card: charges objects like a scroll of charging with the same blessed/cursed status. Only Tourists can perform blessed charging.
  • The Orb of Fate: level teleport.
  • The Longbow of Diana: creates 7-16 uncursed arrows if uncursed, 7-21 blessed arrows if blessed, 6-11 cursed arrows if cursed.
  • The Master Key of Thievery: untraps boxes and doors with 100% success.

Invoking a non-artifact crystal ball is exactly the same as applying it.

Variants

Many variants introduce new artifacts, and thus new possible invoke effects.

SLASH'EM

SLASH'EM introduces a number of new artifacts that can be invoked:[4]

  • The Candle of Eternal Flame: summons a (tame) fire elemental.
  • The Eye of the Beholder: reduces all non-undead monsters in eye's line of sight to 1/3 HP and reduces luck and alignment by 3 with luck above -9. Instadeath with luck below -9.
  • The Gauntlets of Defense: toggles invisibility on/off.
  • The Great Dagger of Glaurgnaa: boost in spell energy.
  • The Hand of Vecna: summons 4-7 tame graveyard creatures and reduces alignment and luck by 3 with luck above -9. Does 5-24 damage to player with luck below -9.
  • Holy Spear of Light: creates a lit field of a 12 square radius. This damages undead and demons in a 9 square radius.
  • The Storm Whistle: summons a (tame) water elemental.
  • The Arkenstone (defunct Dwarf quest artifact): item detection.
  • The Tentacle Staff (defunct Drow quest artifact): level teleport.
  • The Pick of Flandal Steelskin (defunct Gnome quest artifact): toggles conflict on/off.
  • The One Ring (defunct Hobbit quest artifact): toggles conflict on/off.
  • The Staff of Withering (defunct Lycanthrope quest artifact): boost in spell energy.

DynaHack

In DynaHack, the #invoke command is used to invoke, break or rub objects depending on the item chosen.

References

  1. ↑ src/artifact.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1417
  2. ↑ src/artifact.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1433
  3. ↑ src/artifact.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1620
  4. ↑ http://www.angelfire.com/trek/mazewest/spoilers/arti_007e6.txt

This page may need to be updated for the current version of NetHack.

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.6.1. Information on this page may be out of date.

The only objects that can be activated this way are [[crystal ball]]s and most [[quest artifact]]s.{{refsrc|src/artifact.c|1417|nethack=3.6.1}} Artifacts tire after you invoke them, and you cannot do so again for [[rnz]](100) turns (averages 100; can be up to 2000, but 95% of the time it is less than 400). If you invoke again too soon, "You feel that the is ignoring you" and 3d10 turns are added to the wait time.{{refsrc|src/artifact.c|1433|nethack=3.6.1}} For artifacts that give temporary [[extrinsic]]s, the wait time is counted from the moment they're switched off (via an #invoke or otherwise).{{refsrc|src/artifact.c|1620|nethack=3.6.6}} ==Optimal invocation schedule== {{anchor|Optimum invocation schedule}}Invoking strategy is basically a trade-off between the risk of getting nothing and waiting too long. The turns to wait after a successful #invoke versus probability of success are graphed below (assuming your experience is <=17):

If you need the artifact reliably, such as emergency healing from the [[Staff of Aesculapius|Staff of Aesculapius]], you should treat it like prayer - #invoke only in dire need.
